title: Radical Orthodoxy 5: Postmodernism? NO. Gratitude, Humility, Courage, Mercy and Justice, YES.
description:
Karen talks with Michael, Nate and Matt as they decode the 5th principle of Radical Orthodoxy.

Some of the ideas tossed around, without attribution:

Radical Orthodoxy uses the toolbox of Postmodernism without fear, since PM is grounding its first principles in the finite and RO is grounded in the infinite where there is no fear.

To defeat postmodernism which is a rationally coherent argument, it is necessary to outcompete its narrative of power with a narrative of charity and reconciliation.

You will see faith when it occurs in nature. The excellence of the unsaid. Faith is a work of art in the negative space. The unseen gives shape to the seen. 

Patience is not killing time. Rather it is making a space. That same space is created by true listening, silence, receptivity, learning. It is the negative space that defines the focus. Since you cannot rationally elaborate first principles, you have to rely on other ways of knowing, of participating in the unknown.
The Church participates in the coming of the eschaton. The eucharist is key.
We are still retreating but perhaps the YouTube conversations show that while retreating, we are gathering resolve to turn around, to move towards the embodied and the communal and to gather courage.

Radical Orthodoxy operates through the notion of Gift.  This brings up the deep linkage between Courage and Truth. Jordan Peterson says that Humility is Courage. C. S. Lewis said that Courage is every virtue at its testing point.

More information in audible books than in printed ones. Even more information in online conversations due to the spaces between, the relationships between the speakers, and the relationships between the speakers and the listeners.

If you assume there is no God (postmodernism), you are actually saying, Assume that I am God. 

From the Phaedo, you get the marriage of the logos and enchantment, the idea that the value of myth is its ability to enchant us to think the good in spite of all present evidence. JBP says to assume that whatever comes into being due to speaking the truth is good regardless of what it may look like.

The underlying assumption must be that God is good, all the time, regardless of what things look like. Let that be the substrate, the foundation, and let that also be the telos, the vision of where we're headed.
